intro: Sida tracyi, commonly known as Tracy's mallows, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems, heart-shaped leaves, and showy yellow flowers that bloom in the summer. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. Sida tracyi is adapted to withstand drought conditions and is often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements.
